description.summary: A loosely defined region in the western North Atlantic Ocean where ships and aircraft have allegedly disappeared under mysterious circumstances. The area roughly forms a triangle between Miami, Bermuda, and Puerto Rico.
description.full: The Bermuda Triangle is a region in the western Atlantic Ocean where numerous ships and aircraft have disappeared under circumstances that have been characterized as mysterious or unexplained. The term was coined by writer Vincent Gaddis in 1964. The boundaries of the triangle cover approximately 500,000 square miles of ocean between Miami (Florida), Bermuda, and San Juan (Puerto Rico). Reports include compass malfunctions, electronic failures, unusual weather phenomena, and complete disappearances without distress signals. While many attribute these incidents to paranormal or extraterrestrial causes, skeptics point to statistical analysis, human error, and natural oceanographic and meteorological phenomena as explanations. The U.S. Coast Guard and other maritime authorities do not recognize the Bermuda Triangle as particularly hazardous compared to other heavily-traveled ocean regions.

etymology.origin: The term 'Bermuda Triangle' was coined by writer Vincent Gaddis in a 1964 article for Argosy magazine titled 'The Deadly Bermuda Triangle.'
etymology.meaning: Named for the triangular area defined by three geographic points: Miami, Bermuda, and Puerto Rico

origins.cultural_roots: Maritime folklore of mysterious disappearances in the area dates back centuries. Spanish sailors reported strange occurrences as early as Columbus's voyages.

history.modern_era: The Bermuda Triangle remains a cultural phenomenon despite scientific debunking. Modern GPS and communication technology have reduced incidents, but the area remains a heavily-trafficked maritime and aviation route. Media continues to feature the mystery in documentaries and entertainment.

statistics.notes: Exact numbers disputed. Many incidents have prosaic explanations when investigated thoroughly.

notable.name: Flight 19
notable.description: Five TBM Avenger torpedo bombers (Flight 19) disappeared during a routine training mission from Fort Lauderdale Naval Air Station. The flight leader reported compass malfunctions and disorientation. Radio transmissions indicated the aircraft were lost. A PBM Mariner rescue seaplane sent to find them also vanished. All 14 crew members of Flight 19 and 13 crew of the rescue plane were lost. No wreckage was ever conclusively found.
notable.official_explanation: Navigation error, aircraft ran out of fuel and crashed at sea
alternative_theories: Compass anomalies caused by magnetic variations

notable.name: USS Cyclops

location.description: En route from Barbados to Baltimore

notable.description: The USS Cyclops, a massive U.S. Navy collier ship, disappeared without a trace with 306 crew and passengers aboard. The ship departed Barbados on March 4, 1918, bound for Baltimore and was never seen again. No distress signal was sent. No wreckage was ever found. This remains the single largest loss of life in U.S. Navy history not related to combat.
notable.official_explanation: Unknown - possibly structural failure, enemy attack, or storm

factors: Largest single loss in Navy history

notable.name: Star Tiger
notable.description: British South American Airways Avro Tudor IV aircraft Star Tiger disappeared while flying from Santa Maria in the Azores to Bermuda. The aircraft sent routine position reports, then vanished. All 31 people aboard were lost. No wreckage was found despite extensive searches.
sources: UK Ministry of Civil Aviation Report, 1948

notable.name: Star Ariel
notable.description: Sister ship to Star Tiger, this Avro Tudor IV also disappeared without trace. Flying from Bermuda to Kingston, Jamaica, with 20 people aboard, the aircraft sent routine messages then vanished. No distress call, no wreckage found. The Tudor IV was subsequently withdrawn from service.
notable.official_explanation: Unknown - led to withdrawal of Tudor IV from passenger service
alternative_theories: Structural weakness in Tudor IV design

factors: Led to grounding of aircraft model

sources: UK Ministry of Civil Aviation Report, 1949

notable.name: SS Marine Sulphur Queen
notable.description: T2 tanker carrying molten sulfur disappeared in good weather with 39 crew. No distress signal was sent. Coast Guard found debris but no bodies. Investigation revealed the ship was in poor condition and should not have been at sea.
notable.official_explanation: Structural failure - ship broke apart at sea
alternative_theories: Hull failure due to poor maintenance
